elements.content: Fine chemical and pharmaceutical companies often employ reactive crystallization or precipitation to make crystalline intermediates and finished products. In this work, the supercritical reactive crystallization route is used for the precipitation of diverse metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). 1D and 2D MOFs were obtained by reacting either bypyridil (two linking positions) or triazine (three linking positions)-based bridging molecules, respectively, with supercritical CO2 soluble M­(hfacac)2 (where M = Zn2+ or Cu2+ and hfacac– stands for hexafluoroacetylacetonate). Additionally, miscellaneous reactions were designed for the crystallization of 3D MOFs in scCO2, embracing the precipitation of MIL-88B­(Fe), ZIF-8, and a new Zn2+–curcumin coordination polymer. Obtained crystals in each case were analyzed from a morphological point of view by scanning electron microscopy analysis to elucidate potential formation mechanisms. The focus was on the obtained crystal habits at different reaction points, linked to the precipitation mode and the role of kinetic and thermodynamic crystal growth control. The supercritical procedure led to the crystallization of stable hierarchical nanostructures with micro- and mesoporosity and the precipitation of nanocrystals.

Additionally, miscellaneous reactions were designed for the crystallization of 3D MOFs in scCO2, embracing the precipitation of MIL-88B(Fe), ZIF-8, and a new Zn2+-curcumin coordination polymer. Obtained crystals in each case were analyzed from a morphological point of view by scanning electron microscopy analysis to elucidate potential formation mechanisms. elements.content: Supercritical CO2 precipitation is used to create 1D, 2D, and 3D metal−organic frameworks with different morphologies. Crystals were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy. This procedure resulted in crystallization of stable hierarchical nanostructures with micro- and mesoporosity and precipitation of nanocrystals.

elements.content: The 21st century is witnessing the development of many supercritical CO2 (scCO2) advanced nanomanufacturing processes for simple and composite products, mainly in the chemistry, food, pharmaceutical, and textile industries. In these techniques, CO2, an innocuous and extremely well-characterized substance, is used as a solvent. In the mentioned industries, crystallization methods in scCO2 have become viable alternatives to conventional organic solvent routes. The fundamental differences among the already developed supercritical crystallization techniques concern the role of scCO2, used either as a solvent, in the rapid expansion of supercritical solutions (RESS), antisolvent, in the group of gas antisolvent (GAS) techniques, or solute, in the particles from gas saturated solutions (PGSS) route. A common feature in all of them is that the fluid is expanded through a restriction device or nozzle to create supersaturation in a spraying process. These methods are all recrystallization techniques applied to different materials for purification and particle size redistribution (micronization) without significantly affecting the chemical composition of the starting product. These complex crystallization processes performed in scCO2 required the use of sophisticated equipment involving high pressure pumps. As an alternative, the dry ice-originated supercritical and liquid CO2 technique has been previously described for extraction applications. This technique requires only two high-pressure stainless steel vessels, one for packing dry ice and the other for containing the sample of interest, two water baths for temperature control purposes, and a box of dry ice. Concurrently, the use of scCO2 as a solvent in chemical reactions has been notably developed in the last 20 years, finding applications in oxidation, hydrogenation and hydroformylation reactions, dispersion and free-radical polymerization, homogeneous and heterogeneous transition-metal catalysis, enzymatic chemistry, and so on.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The 21st century is witnessing the development of many supercritical CO2 (scCO2) advanced nanomanufacturing processes for simple and composite products, mainly in the chemistry, food, pharmaceutical, and textile industries. In these techniques, CO2, an innocuous and extremely well-characterized substance, is used as a solvent. In the mentioned industries, crystallization methods in scCO2 have become viable alternatives to conventional organic solvent routes. The fundamental differences among the already developed supercritical crystallization techniques concern the role of scCO2, used either as a solvent, in the rapid expansion of supercritical solutions (RESS), antisolvent, in the group of gas antisolvent (GAS) techniques, or solute, in the particles from gas saturated solutions (PGSS) route. A common feature in all of them is that the fluid is expanded through a restriction device or nozzle to create supersaturation in a spraying process. These methods are all recrystallization techniques applied to different materials for purification and particle size redistribution (micronization) without significantly affecting the chemical composition of the starting product. These complex crystallization processes performed in scCO2 required the use of sophisticated equipment involving high pressure pumps. As an alternative, the dry ice-originated supercritical and liquid CO2 technique has been previously described for extraction applications. This technique requires only two high-pressure stainless steel vessels, one for packing dry ice and the other for containing the sample of interest, two water baths for temperature control purposes, and a box of dry ice. Concurrently, the use of scCO2 as a solvent in chemical reactions has been notably developed in the last 20 years, finding applications in oxidation, hydrogenation and hydroformylation reactions, dispersion and free-radical polymerization, homogeneous and heterogeneous transition-metal catalysis, enzymatic chemistry, and so on.

elements.content: For scCO2, despite the current acquired knowledge in crystallization on one side and chemical reactions on the other, the study of reactive crystallization processes in which precipitation occurs by chemical reaction of two (or more) species has not received the same level of attention. The majority of examples available in the literature are limited to the use of scCO2 as a reagent in the crystallization of calcium and other carbonates and in the formation of metallocene derivatives. More recently, crystallization of cocrystals and metal–organic adducts using scCO2 as antisolvent and solvent, respectively, has been described. On the basis of the analysis of these state of the art studies, this report is part of ongoing work on the synthesis through reactive crystallization of coordination polymers or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in scCO2 through the right choice of building blocks soluble in this fluid.

The majority of examples available in the literature are limited to the use of scCO2 as a reagent in the crystallization of calcium and other carbonates and in the formation of metallocene derivatives. More recently, crystallization of cocrystals and metal-organic adducts using scCO2 as antisolvent and solvent, respectively, has been described. On the basis of the analysis of these state of the art studies, this report is part of ongoing work on the synthesis through reactive crystallization of coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in scCO2 through the right choice of building blocks soluble in this fluid.

elements.content: MOFs are a class of crystalline materials produced by the coordination of transition-metal cations with multidentate organic linkers, forming extended frameworks that often are highly porous. These are materials primarily proposed for adsorption applications in hydrogen and carbon dioxide storage and gas purification and separation but also for catalysis, sensing, and biomedical uses. The solvothermal technique is most commonly employed for their synthesis. However, this is an energetic and time-consuming approach performed in polluting organic solvents, which needs extensive cleaning, drying, and activation periods after product crystallization. ScCO2 appears as an attractive medium to synthesize these materials due to the potential solubility of numerous MOF precursors in this fluid, including organometallic compounds and some typical organic bridging molecules such as pyridine-based linkers, thus allowing their formation by reactive crystallization. Indeed, the use of compressed CO2 in the field of MOFs has been mainly limited to the postsynthesis activation by cleansing entrapped undesired byproducts or solvents, performed either by batch solvent exchange/scCO2 treatment or directly from the solvated crystals by flowing scCO2.

elements.content: In this work, conceptual methods for batch reactive crystallization in scCO2 of several coordination polymers are described using seven case studies, including 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. The purpose of this study is to perform a comprehensive analysis of the different morphologies obtained when precipitated using reactive crystallization in this fluid and, hence, to ascertain possible formation mechanisms. The amazing crystal shapes obtained in scCO2 are analyzed from a crystal growth mechanistic point of view by taking into account nonclassical routes of crystallization, often proposed for complex structures of zeolites and MOFs. Research focused on tuning and controlling the crystal habit and size in the nanometric range of MOFs is an important scientific goal because some intrinsic properties can be tailored by modifying these parameters.

Sample preparation under scCO2 was carried out in the high pressure equipment schematized in . A stainless steel reactor of 100 mL volume (Thar Process) equipped with two opposite sapphire windows was used for synthesis. In a typical experiment, the autoclave was charged with ca. 100 mg of the metal precursor and the corresponding stoichiometric amount of organic linker calculated to obtain the target product. The reagents and a small magnetic bar stirrer were added to a 10 mL Pyrex vial capped with filter paper and placed within the reactor. In some experiments, a 2% v/v of a cosolvent, either EtOH or dioxane, was also added. The autoclave was then sealed. Tested experimental conditions are given in .

elements.content: In a typical experiment, the system was pressurized up to 15–20 MPa and heated at a temperature of either 313 or 333 K. The vessel was operated in batch mode under stirring for time periods ranging from 1 to 90 h. Finally, the reactor was slowly depressurized at a rate of 1–2 MPa·min–1. Samples were cleaned by rinsing with a continuous flow of scCO2 at 20 MPa and 313 K.

elements.content: The crystallinity of MOF products was studied by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Siemens D5000. For systems with a resolved and published crystal structure, the recorded XRD was compared with that of the single crystal to ascertain the success of the reaction. For the rest of the compounds in which the precipitated crystals did not have the size and quality required for structural elucidation through single crystal techniques, elemental analysis was used to qualitatively elucidate the molecular formulas. Measurements were performed in a Flash EA2000 Thermo Fisher Scientific analyzer. Surface area was determined by N2 adsorption at 77 K using an ASAP 2000 Micromeritics instrument. Samples were previously outgassed under reduced pressure at 333 K for 24 h. Morphological features were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Quanta FEI 200).
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The crystallinity of MOF products was studied by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Siemens D5000. For systems with a resolved and published crystal structure, the recorded XRD was compared with that of the single crystal to ascertain the success of the reaction. For the rest of the compounds in which the precipitated crystals did not have the size and quality required for structural elucidation through single crystal techniques, elemental analysis was used to qualitatively elucidate the molecular formulas. Measurements were performed in a Flash EA2000 Thermo Fisher Scientific analyzer. Surface area was determined by N2 adsorption at 77 K using an ASAP 2000 Micromeritics instrument. Samples were previously outgassed under reduced pressure at 333 K for 24 h. Morphological features were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Quanta FEI 200).

elements.content: Crystal habit in MOFs depends on numerous factors, including the chemistry of both the metal ion and the organic linker influencing the kinetics and the equilibrium morphology as well as the solvent used for the synthesis. The solvent effect is a fundamental issue in controlling reaction kinetics and thermodynamics during coordination and nucleation steps as well as in the further crystal growth. In a conventional solvothermal MOF reactive crystallization process, the reaction between the metal center and the linker has been described as very fast in comparison to mass transfer of reagents from the bulk to the growing crystals and crystal growth rate. This observation can be extended to processes carried out in scCO2, in which interphase transport limitations on the reaction kinetics are also minimized. In the supercritical approach, the solubility of reagents in scCO2, even being significant, is usually very low in comparison to that of conventional liquids. The solubility of growing units in scCO2, constituted by the reaction of the two reagents, is expected to be still lower due to the higher molecular weight of these units. As a result, high local supersaturations are generated in scCO2 by fast chemical reaction, thus leading to extensive nucleation and the precipitation of small crystals, essentially nanometric particles. Moreover, conducting chemical reactions under supercritical conditions affords opportunities to manipulate the reaction environment (solvent properties) by controlling not only the temperature but also the pressure. Finally, reaction and separation unit operations are integrated in situ or after pressure reduction precipitation. All of these factors lead to the observation of fascinating crystal habits in scCO2, some of them not previously described in the literature for hybrid coordination polymers. Herein, results obtained in scCO2 corresponding to 1D, 2D, and 3D MOFs are presented.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal habit in MOFs depends on numerous factors, including the chemistry of both the metal ion and the organic linker influencing the kinetics and the equilibrium morphology as well as the solvent used for the synthesis. The solvent effect is a fundamental issue in controlling reaction kinetics and thermodynamics during coordination and nucleation steps as well as in the further crystal growth. In a conventional solvothermal MOF reactive crystallization process, the reaction between the metal center and the linker has been described as very fast in comparison to mass transfer of reagents from the bulk to the growing crystals and crystal growth rate. This observation can be extended to processes carried out in scCO2, in which interphase transport limitations on the reaction kinetics are also minimized. In the supercritical approach, the solubility of reagents in scCO2, even being significant, is usually very low in comparison to that of conventional liquids. The solubility of growing units in scCO2, constituted by the reaction of the two reagents, is expected to be still lower due to the higher molecular weight of these units. As a result, high local supersaturations are generated in scCO2 by fast chemical reaction, thus leading to extensive nucleation and the precipitation of small crystals, essentially nanometric particles. Moreover, conducting chemical reactions under supercritical conditions affords opportunities to manipulate the reaction environment (solvent properties) by controlling not only the temperature but also the pressure. Finally, reaction and separation unit operations are integrated in situ or after pressure reduction precipitation. All of these factors lead to the observation of fascinating crystal habits in scCO2, some of them not previously described in the literature for hybrid coordination polymers. Herein, results obtained in scCO2 corresponding to 1D, 2D, and 3D MOFs are presented.

elements.content: Taking into account the common solvating properties of scCO2, neutral metal­(II) acetylacetonate complexes with different degrees of fluorination were chosen as the primary building blocks. For these compounds, solubility values in scCO2 are reported in the literature. For instance, the solubility of Zn­(acac)2 at 313 K and 20 MPa has a value of 1.7 × 10–7 mole fraction, while the solubility of Cu­(hfacac)2 at 313 K and similar pressure increased to a value of 2.42 × 10–3 mole fraction. The fluoride content determines the solubility in the compressed fluid. The iron­(III) nitrate is totally insoluble in scCO2, and the aid of a cosolvent (dioxane) was needed for the success of the reaction. Generally, the cosolvent is chosen between solvents with a medium polarity index (ca. 5), including short-chain alcohols, esters or ketones, and dioxane, although highly polar dimethyl sulfoxide or even water (polarity index 8 and 10, respectively) have also been used.

elements.content: The solubility of the linkers was qualitatively estimated by visual observation through the reactor sapphire windows. The added amount of either bpp or bpe was found to completely dissolve in scCO2 under working experimental conditions. 4-TPT and Hmim have from limited to null solubility in this fluid. However, the reaction with the metal in both series (highly and limited solubility in scCO2) occurs, and the formation of the target MOF is achieved without the addition of a cosolvent. Finally, the addition of a cosolvent (ethanol) was necessary to react the heavy curcumin (CMM) linker with the metal.

elements.content: 1D coordination polymers were prepared by reacting M­(hfacac)2 (Zn2+ or Cu2+) metal center with a bipyridine linker, either bpp or bpe (). Chosen linkers are linear bidentate N donor ligands having the possibility of different relative orientation of the pyridine rings. In the M­(hfacac)2, the two hfacac– molecules are arranged occupying the four equatorial coordination positions in the metal complex, leaving the two axial positions free, which allows 1D chain growth by reaction with the bidentate linker. Both bpp and bpe linkers were observed to be highly soluble in scCO2. M­(hfacac)2 complexes also had a significant solubility in scCO2, which is determined by the high fluoride content in the ligand. As a result of the high solubility of both reagents in scCO2, the corresponding coordination polymer could be prepared by reactive crystallization in this fluid at the standard conditions of 333 K and 20 MPa without requiring any additive or cosolvent (). Visual observation of the reaction through the sapphire windows of the high pressure reactor revealed a fast episode of crystal formation occurring upon mixing the reagents. Hence, runs of 4 h were considered adequate to finalize the crystallization process.
elements.clean_text:
1D Coordination Polymers

1D coordination polymers were prepared by reacting M(hfacac)2 (Zn2+ or Cu2+) metal center with a bipyridine linker, either bpp or bpe (). Chosen linkers are linear bidentate N donor ligands having the possibility of different relative orientation of the pyridine rings. In the M(hfacac)2, the two hfacac- molecules are arranged occupying the four equatorial coordination positions in the metal complex, leaving the two axial positions free, which allows 1D chain growth by reaction with the bidentate linker. Both bpp and bpe linkers were observed to be highly soluble in scCO2. M(hfacac)2 complexes also had a significant solubility in scCO2, which is determined by the high fluoride content in the ligand. As a result of the high solubility of both reagents in scCO2, the corresponding coordination polymer could be prepared by reactive crystallization in this fluid at the standard conditions of 333 K and 20 MPa without requiring any additive or cosolvent (). Visual observation of the reaction through the sapphire windows of the high pressure reactor revealed a fast episode of crystal formation occurring upon mixing the reagents. Hence, runs of 4 h were considered adequate to finalize the crystallization process.

elements.content: Elemental analysis indicated that the three different 1D MOFs crystallized in scCO2 () have the general formulas [M­(hfacac)2(bipyridine)]. Nevertheless, only the structure of the [Cu­(hfacac)2(bpp)] product has been reported in the literature. The published XRD pattern for this phase is analogous to the one recorded for the scCO2 precipitated crystals, indicating a similar crystal structure in both cases (a). This structure is described as ordered sinusoidal 1D chains, resulting in two sets of parallel planes. Macroscopically, SEM analysis of the precipitated products shows the formation of 2D crystals (films and platelets) for the three MOFs. The crystals have micrometric lengths in two directions and a nanometric thickness (). Specifically, [Cu­(hfacac)2(bpp)] shows 2D “sheet-like” fragile crystals broken at some points (a); [Cu­(hfacac)2(bpe)] displays 2D polyhedral platelets of ca. 1–3 × 0.5–1 μm and a thickness of less than 50 nm (b), and [Zn­(hfacac)2(bpe)] is constituted by 2D isometric platelets of 2–5 μm diameter and a thickness of 200–500 nm (c). This crystal habit indicates kinetically controlled anisotropic growth across a specific set of crystallographic directions, which gives rise to single crystals that are elongated normal to those faces. Apparent bulk crystal morphology corresponds to the slowest growth directions. These compounds showed negligible N2 adsorption, but assembly of coordination polymers into a 2D crystal habit facilitates their implementation in important application fields such as sensing, where the signal transduction schemes requires the fabrication of thin film optics and proton and electric conduction in films.

elements.content: The approach followed for the precipitation of 2D coordination polymers in scCO2 relied on the utilization of a triazine with three coordinating points (4-TPT in ). 3-Connector triazines are interesting for the synthesis of MOFs because its rigidity and trigonal geometry allows the formation of highly symmetrical extended planar 2D frameworks enclosing nanocavities. In comparison to bidentate pyridines, the 4-TPT linker was found to be only slightly soluble in scCO2 at 333 K and 20 MPa. Therefore, to guarantee the accomplishment of the reaction, the running time was extended to 20 h ().
elements.clean_text:
2D Coordination Polymers

The approach followed for the precipitation of 2D coordination polymers in scCO2 relied on the utilization of a triazine with three coordinating points (4-TPT in ). 3-Connector triazines are interesting for the synthesis of MOFs because its rigidity and trigonal geometry allows the formation of highly symmetrical extended planar 2D frameworks enclosing nanocavities. In comparison to bidentate pyridines, the 4-TPT linker was found to be only slightly soluble in scCO2 at 333 K and 20 MPa. Therefore, to guarantee the accomplishment of the reaction, the running time was extended to 20 h ().

elements.content: Using elemental analysis data, the composition [(Zn­(hfacac)2)1.5(4-TPT)] was estimated, which corresponds to a structure extended in two directions. b depicts the X-ray diffraction pattern recorded for the precipitated crystalline material. The structure of this phase has not been found described in the literature. Macroscopically, regular cubic polyhedra of several micrometers in length were observed by SEM analysis (a).

elements.content: The micrometric particles have well-defined flat polygonal faces, straight edges, and sharp corners, but they contain a myriad of nanometric entities attached to the surface (b). This observation indicates that nonclassical 3D growth by particle attachment on the surface could be the dominant crystal growth mechanism. The small entities have different morphologies, from crystallites to numerous aggregated amorphous spheres (c). These amorphous nanoparticles have been described to undergo a molecular rearrangement and growth into small crystals to further integrate structurally into the underlying crystal lattice. In parallel with this process, a 2D layer growth pathway driven by monomer/oligomer addition seems to contribute to crystal growth because advancement fronts can be observed on the surface of some of the precipitated crystals (d). The mechanism of oligomer addition to crystals in scCO2 would closely resemble that of the classical route because the oligomers should be constituted by a very limited number of molecular entities to preserve their solubility in this fluid with low solvent capacity. It has been suggested for zeolites that this second mode of crystallization occurs when solutions are near equilibrium and precursor concentration is low. N2 adsorption displayed a type I isotherm typical of microporous solids having relatively small external surfaces. The micropore surface area measured for this product was on the order of 480 m2·g–1. These 2D systems have been studied as a motif with sorption capability between layers.

This observation indicates that nonclassical 3D growth by particle attachment on the surface could be the dominant crystal growth mechanism. The small entities have different morphologies, from crystallites to numerous aggregated amorphous spheres (c). elements.content: The synthesis of 3D MOFs often involves high molecular weight or polar molecules with low solubility in scCO2 which, in principle, would discard many synthetic possibilities. However, this work demonstrates that the synthesis protocols in scCO2 could be extended to 3D structures in MOFs, involving linkers from the carboxylate and imidazole families (). Moreover, the synthesis of a new structure with a natural linker, in this case CMM (), was successfully achieved. In some experiments, the addition of a 2% v/v liquid cosolvent, either EtOH or dioxane, was necessary due to the low solubility of used reagents in scCO2 (). Remarkable 3D structures with complex morphologies were obtained. The crystallographic complexity of the structures of these 3D MOFs makes sometimes difficult to obtain high-quality single crystals via crystal growth. To analyze the crystallization mechanism, multiple identical runs were performed under similar experimental conditions to study in each time period the crystal growth progress ex situ by XRD and SEM analysis. These experiments indicated that end products were not obtained by direct reaction, but most likely the process involves the formation of amorphous or semicrystalline metastable phases before undergoing subsequent transition to the thermodynamically stable phase.

3D Coordination Polymers

The synthesis of 3D MOFs often involves high molecular weight or polar molecules with low solubility in scCO2 which, in principle, would discard many synthetic possibilities. However, this work demonstrates that the synthesis protocols in scCO2 could be extended to 3D structures in MOFs, involving linkers from the carboxylate and imidazole families (). Moreover, the synthesis of a new structure with a natural linker, in this case CMM (), was successfully achieved. In some experiments, the addition of a 2% v/v liquid cosolvent, either EtOH or dioxane, was necessary due to the low solubility of used reagents in scCO2 (). Remarkable 3D structures with complex morphologies were obtained. The crystallographic complexity of the structures of these 3D MOFs makes sometimes difficult to obtain high-quality single crystals via crystal growth. To analyze the crystallization mechanism, multiple identical runs were performed under similar experimental conditions to study in each time period the crystal growth progress ex situ by XRD and SEM analysis. These experiments indicated that end products were not obtained by direct reaction, but most likely the process involves the formation of amorphous or semicrystalline metastable phases before undergoing subsequent transition to the thermodynamically stable phase.

elements.content: The first attempted experiments for the formation of 3D MOFs in scCO2 were directed to the crystallization of the MIL-88B­(Fe) phase by reacting Fe­(NO3)3 and the dicarboxylate H2bdc (). The reaction was performed at 20 MPa and 333 K and required the addition of a 2% v/v of dioxane (). Moreover, an intensive cleaning step with ethanol to eliminate residual reagents contaminating the final product was necessary. Under solvothermal conditions, MIL-88B solids with general formula (M3+)3OX­(solvent)2(−O2C–R–CO2−)3]·nH2O·MeOH (M = Fe3+ or Cr3+; X = F–, OH–, Cl–, or –O2C–CH3), have been synthesized. These structures are typical examples of highly flexible MOFs in which the unit cell volume undergoes a reversible expansion from the closed (dehydrated) to the open (fully solvated) forms, with enormous changes in the volume of the unit cell. The XRD pattern of the precipitated sample was in agreement with the profile reported for the MIL-88B­(Cr) phase in ref (a). The elemental analysis indicated the probable precipitation in scCO2 of a compound with the general formula [Fe3O­(H2O)2OH­(bdc)3]. However, the end product was highly contaminated with residual Fe­(NO3)3 reagent and contained noticeable amounts of water. As expected, N2 adsorption gave a low surface area value for this compound on the order of 60 m2·g–1 due to the closed-pore characteristics of the dry structure. SEM images showed spindle-shaped elongated crystals of 0.5–2 μm (), morphology similar to that observed for microwave-assisted solvothermally precipitated MIL-88B­(Fe) crystals.

elements.content: In a second series of experiments, ZIF-8, with formulas [Zn­(2-mim)2] (2-mim = methylimidazole) and sodalite topology, was synthesized in pure scCO2 from Zn­(acac)2 and H2-mim (). ZIF-8 is currently one of the most extensively investigated zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of MOFs. Using scCO2 as the exclusive synthesis medium, the straight precipitation of an empty-pore ZIF-8 nanopowder was successfully achieved in a 10 h run at 333 K (), as shown by the agreement between the XRD patterns of the synthesized and published single crystal data (b). However, the development of an extra peak at 2θ = 11.1° indicates the simultaneous formation of ZIF-8 and the kinetically favored phase described as ZIF-L. Under similar experimental conditions, to precipitate pure ZIF-8, the temperature must be decreased to 313 K in the 10 h run (b). The reversible type I isotherm was recorded for these samples. The micropore surface area of the as-synthesized sample at 313 K was on the order of 1200 m2·g–1, comparable to the reported value in the literature for conventionally precipitated products. In the supercritical procedure, from the two used reagents, only Zn­(acac)2 had a significant solubility in scCO2. However, the reaction with 2-Hmim took place with a high yield, even at the soft conditions of 313 K. Previous studies have shown that the formation of ZIF-8 crystals occurs through tetranuclear and related oligomeric Zn2+ species, in which the cations are bridged by 2-mim ligands. Therefore, one possible explanation for the mechanism occurring in scCO2 is that the reaction goes through the formation of low molecular weight soluble species involving both reagents, which assembled to form the intermediate kinetic amorphous phase. Indeed, this low degree of crystallinity was observed in the XRD pattern of a 1 h sample produced at 313 K (b). This diffractogram also showed the presence of an intermediate phase with an intense peak at ca. 2θ = 12°. SEM analysis indicated that the 1 h sample was mainly constituted by amorphous spherical particles that agglomerate in large units (a). However, a closed view showed the presence of some rhombohedral structures with smooth surfaces already developed (b), potentially corresponding to the metastable phase observed in the diffractogram recorded at 1 h (b). Further analysis at 10 h indicated the presence of large agglomerates of 50–200 μm (c), surprisingly depicting pores of 2–5 μm in diameter, which is a unique morphology described for the first time for this type of crystalline product. These macropores are likely formed in a top-down process from the agglomerated mass of crystals during the step of expansion and evacuation of the compressed CO2 trapped into the ZIF-8 structural pores and in the interparticle pore volume. Local magnification revealed that the macroscopic assemblies were constituted by cubic primary nanometric particles with crystal sizes on the order of 50–200 nm (d). A porous hierarchical microstructure is thus obtained, involving structural ZIF-8 micropores together with the described macropores. Such cellular structures have previously been observed in amorphous polymeric systems prepared using scCO2, but they are a novelty for crystalline coordination polymers. Hierarchical meso/microporous structures have been described for other MOFs precipitated in scCO2 but using complex setups with ionic liquids and/or surfactants.

elements.content: As a third example of the synthesis of 3D MOFs in scCO2, the CCM molecule () was used as a linker to construct biocompatible materials by reaction with Zn­(acac)2. CCM is a natural hydrophobic polyphenolic diketone extracted from turmeric with relevant anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. It is well-known as a natural coloring pigment in food and, nowadays, its use is also proposed in anticancer therapies. The whole molecule of CCM is almost linear, planar, and rigid, which would benefit the formation of porous and 3D stable frameworks. A highly porous 3D MOF based on CCM and Zn2+ is described in the literature with formulas [Zn3(CCM)2] involving 7 N,N′-dimethylacetamide and 3 EtOH molecules. Taking into account that the curcumin pigment can be efficiently extracted from the turmeric rhizome by scCO2 with EtOH as a cosolvent, the possibility of preparing curcumin MOFs by reactive crystallization in this medium was examined. The reaction between the highly soluble Zn­(acac)2 and the slightly soluble curcumin was performed in scCO2 with 2% v/v EtOH at 333 K and 20 MPa. A solid stable in air was thus crystallized at 333 K after only 1 h (). The solubility of the obtained product in water and common organic solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, acetonitrile, N,N′-dimethylformamide, and dimethyl sulfoxide was negligible, which is a typical characteristic of coordination polymers. The formulas deduced for this solid from the elemental analysis agree with the stoichiometry of the reported compound, i.e., [Zn3(CCM)2], with a small amount of EtOH and/or H2O. In view of these results, it seems plausible to assume a 3D structure for this phase. However, the recorded XRD pattern (c) did not have any resemblance with the published phase in ref .

elements.content: SEM analysis indicated that monodispersed hierarchical flower-like structures with a typical diameter in the range of 5–8 μm were precipitated (a). These microcrystals were built from several tens of 2D nanosheets (petals) with thickness on the nanometer scale, ca. 50–70 nm, slightly curved, and densely interpenetrated (b). Each nanopetal was constructed from nanobricks (c). The fabrication of stable 3D flower-like hierarchical architectures, made by the integration of nanobuilding blocks, in this case 2D nanopetals, with some order and flexibility, is an elegant approach found in nature to increase systems stability. One very well-known example is the formation of the flower-shaped morphologies of crystallized calcium sulfate, known as desert roses. In the laboratory, these attractive architectures have been successfully fabricated for a wide variety of materials involving mainly inorganic compounds. For hybrid coordination polymers, several examples have been described and synthesized by solvothermal techniques, involving Zn2+, Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Ru2+ metal centers and carboxylic or pyridyl linkers. The crystallized products present a type I N2 adsorption isotherm, indicating the precipitation of a microporous system with a surface area of ca. 300 m2·g–1, which corresponded to a considerably high value for an as-synthesized product. Most of this surface area was in the range of the micropore.

elements.content: To analyze the crystallization mechanism, the synthesis in scCO2 was repeated, reducing the temperature and pressure to 313 K and 15 MPa, respectively, with the objective of slowing the kinetics. Under these new experimental conditions, the reaction period must be extended to nearly 100 h to obtain an end product similar to that in the 1 h run performed at 333 K and 20 MPa (). c shows that the XRD patterns of samples obtained at 1 h (333 K, 20 MPa) and 90 h (313 K, 15 MPa) were similar, indicating the same crystal structure in both cases. Although the exact formation mechanism of the assembled hierarchical structure is unclear, on the basis of the literature and SEM observations in the present study, it can be assumed that the formation of the 3D flower-like particles proceeded through the combination of primary particle oriented self-assembly in a nonclassical crystal growth route and Ostwald ripening. The mechanistic analysis is schematized in and analyzed with SEM micrographs taken at different reaction times. In an early stage of the crystallization (1 h after mixing the reagents), agglomerated spherical particles are observed (step 1, a). The recorded XRD diffractogram of this sample corresponded to an amorphous phase (c). Freshly formed nuclei are thermodynamically unstable and aggregated in spherical primary particles of ca. 1 μm to minimize the interfacial area (step 2, b). At 20 h of reaction time, the amorphous aggregates coexists with 2D plate-like petal growth by oriented attachment (step 3, c). The XRD pattern of the 20 h sample still showed a large degree of amorphicity but also displayed an intense peak of a metastable crystalline phase at 2θ = 7° (c). Longer reaction times in the period of 20–90 h led to the formation of 3D flowers by rotation of adjacent nanopetals (step 4). A closed view of these incipient flower-like crystals shows that the nanosheets extend outward from a center and also attach to the neighboring ones (d). Growth continues in the nanoflowers by Ostwald ripening (step 5) feed by small particles produced in secondary nucleation episodes (e). Finally, after ca. 90 h of the reaction, a micrometric spherical flower-like structures is formed (f). The arrangement of primary nanoparticles into iso-oriented petals via oriented attachment was clearly visible in the petals of the 333 K (1 h) sample (c). However, in the 90 h runs performed at 313 K, the nanoparticles had enough time to fuse together, giving place to single crystal petals with a smooth surface (g). This specific crystal architecture greatly decreases the surface energy of the nanosheets and enhances their stability. In this morphology, mesopores permeate the aggregated crystal, facilitating diffusion in adsorption applications.

elements.content: The presented analysis was intended to be a systematic study of 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymer formation by reactive crystallization in scCO2. The significance of supercritical crystallization processes was described to rely on the possibility of producing homogeneous nucleation steps without the interference of solvent interaction. 1D and 2D coordination polymers were obtained using bidentate and tridentate N donor linkers, i.e., bipyridyl and triazine derivatives, respectively. Known MIL-88B­(Fe) and ZIF-8 and new [Zn3(CCM)2] 3D phases were also obtained in scCO2. Different pathways of crystallization were observed for the studied 3D MOFs. For the MIL-88B­(Fe) system, the mechanism can involve the direct addition to the crystal surface of molecular precursors giving place to particles with a polyhydric habit. Instead, the precipitation of ZIF-8 probably occurs through tetranuclear and related oligomeric Zn2+ soluble species in scCO2 and an amorphous precursor. The most complex crystal growth pathway was observed by the system involving curcumin with a habit represented by hierarchical nanoflowers, resulting from an oriented self-assembly mechanism and ending with Ostwald ripening. The scCO2 process avoids the use of bulk organic liquids, difficult to recover additives, and large excesses of expensive linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The presented analysis was intended to be a systematic study of 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymer formation by reactive crystallization in scCO2. The significance of supercritical crystallization processes was described to rely on the possibility of producing homogeneous nucleation steps without the interference of solvent interaction. 1D and 2D coordination polymers were obtained using bidentate and tridentate N donor linkers, i.e., bipyridyl and triazine derivatives, respectively. Known MIL-88B(Fe) and ZIF-8 and new [Zn3(CCM)2] 3D phases were also obtained in scCO2. Different pathways of crystallization were observed for the studied 3D MOFs. For the MIL-88B(Fe) system, the mechanism can involve the direct addition to the crystal surface of molecular precursors giving place to particles with a polyhydric habit. Instead, the precipitation of ZIF-8 probably occurs through tetranuclear and related oligomeric Zn2+ soluble species in scCO2 and an amorphous precursor. The most complex crystal growth pathway was observed by the system involving curcumin with a habit represented by hierarchical nanoflowers, resulting from an oriented self-assembly mechanism and ending with Ostwald ripening. The scCO2 process avoids the use of bulk organic liquids, difficult to recover additives, and large excesses of expensive linkers.

In a second series of experiments, ZIF-8, with formulas [Zn­(2-mim)2] (2-mim = methylimidazole) and sodalite topology, was synthesized in pure scCO2 from Zn­(acac)2 and H2-mim (). ZIF-8 is currently one of the most extensively investigated zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of MOFs. Using scCO2 as the exclusive synthesis medium, the straight precipitation of an empty-pore ZIF-8 nanopowder was successfully achieved in a 10 h run at 333 K (), as shown by the agreement between the XRD patterns of the synthesized and published single crystal data (b). However, the development of an extra peak at 2θ = 11.1° indicates the simultaneous formation of ZIF-8 and the kinetically favored phase described as ZIF-L. Under similar experimental conditions, to precipitate pure ZIF-8, the temperature must be decreased to 313 K in the 10 h run (b). The reversible type I isotherm was recorded for these samples. The micropore surface area of the as-synthesized sample at 313 K was on the order of 1200 m2·g–1, comparable to the reported value in the literature for conventionally precipitated products. In the supercritical procedure, from the two used reagents, only Zn­(acac)2 had a significant solubility in scCO2. However, the reaction with 2-Hmim took place with a high yield, even at the soft conditions of 313 K. Previous studies have shown that the formation of ZIF-8 crystals occurs through tetranuclear and related oligomeric Zn2+ species, in which the cations are bridged by 2-mim ligands. Therefore, one possible explanation for the mechanism occurring in scCO2 is that the reaction goes through the formation of low molecular weight soluble species involving both reagents, which assembled to form the intermediate kinetic amorphous phase. Indeed, this low degree of crystallinity was observed in the XRD pattern of a 1 h sample produced at 313 K (b). This diffractogram also showed the presence of an intermediate phase with an intense peak at ca. 2θ = 12°. SEM analysis indicated that the 1 h sample was mainly constituted by amorphous spherical particles that agglomerate in large units (a). However, a closed view showed the presence of some rhombohedral structures with smooth surfaces already developed (b), potentially corresponding to the metastable phase observed in the diffractogram recorded at 1 h (b). Further analysis at 10 h indicated the presence of large agglomerates of 50–200 μm (c), surprisingly depicting pores of 2–5 μm in diameter, which is a unique morphology described for the first time for this type of crystalline product. These macropores are likely formed in a top-down process from the agglomerated mass of crystals during the step of expansion and evacuation of the compressed CO2 trapped into the ZIF-8 structural pores and in the interparticle pore volume. Local magnification revealed that the macroscopic assemblies were constituted by cubic primary nanometric particles with crystal sizes on the order of 50–200 nm (d). A porous hierarchical microstructure is thus obtained, involving structural ZIF-8 micropores together with the described macropores. Such cellular structures have previously been observed in amorphous polymeric systems prepared using scCO2, but they are a novelty for crystalline coordination polymers. Hierarchical meso/microporous structures have been described for other MOFs precipitated in scCO2 but using complex setups with ionic liquids and/or surfactants.
cln_elements.clean_text:
MIL-88B(Fe)

The first attempted experiments for the formation of 3D MOFs in scCO2 were directed to the crystallization of the MIL-88B(Fe) phase by reacting Fe(NO3)3 and the dicarboxylate H2bdc (). The reaction was performed at 20 MPa and 333 K and required the addition of a 2% v/v of dioxane (). Moreover, an intensive cleaning step with ethanol to eliminate residual reagents contaminating the final product was necessary. Under solvothermal conditions, MIL-88B solids with general formula (M3+)3OX(solvent)2(-O2C-R-CO2-)3]⋅nH2O⋅MeOH (M = Fe3+ or Cr3+; X = F-, OH-, Cl-, or -O2C-CH3), have been synthesized. These structures are typical examples of highly flexible MOFs in which the unit cell volume undergoes a reversible expansion from the closed (dehydrated) to the open (fully solvated) forms, with enormous changes in the volume of the unit cell. The XRD pattern of the precipitated sample was in agreement with the profile reported for the MIL-88B(Cr) phase in ref  (a). The elemental analysis indicated the probable precipitation in scCO2 of a compound with the general formula [Fe3O(H2O)2OH(bdc)3]. However, the end product was highly contaminated with residual Fe(NO3)3 reagent and contained noticeable amounts of water. As expected, N2 adsorption gave a low surface area value for this compound on the order of 60 m2⋅g-1 due to the closed-pore characteristics of the dry structure. SEM images showed spindle-shaped elongated crystals of 0.5-2 μm (), morphology similar to that observed for microwave-assisted solvothermally precipitated MIL-88B(Fe) crystals. 

ZIF-8

cln_elements.content:
The micrometric particles have well-defined flat polygonal faces, straight edges, and sharp corners, but they contain a myriad of nanometric entities attached to the surface (b). This observation indicates that nonclassical 3D growth by particle attachment on the surface could be the dominant crystal growth mechanism. The small entities have different morphologies, from crystallites to numerous aggregated amorphous spheres (c). These amorphous nanoparticles have been described to undergo a molecular rearrangement and growth into small crystals to further integrate structurally into the underlying crystal lattice. In parallel with this process, a 2D layer growth pathway driven by monomer/oligomer addition seems to contribute to crystal growth because advancement fronts can be observed on the surface of some of the precipitated crystals (d). The mechanism of oligomer addition to crystals in scCO2 would closely resemble that of the classical route because the oligomers should be constituted by a very limited number of molecular entities to preserve their solubility in this fluid with low solvent capacity. It has been suggested for zeolites that this second mode of crystallization occurs when solutions are near equilibrium and precursor concentration is low. N2 adsorption displayed a type I isotherm typical of microporous solids having relatively small external surfaces. The micropore surface area measured for this product was on the order of 480 m2·g–1. These 2D systems have been studied as a motif with sorption capability between layers.

SEM analysis indicated that monodispersed hierarchical flower-like structures with a typical diameter in the range of 5–8 μm were precipitated (a). These microcrystals were built from several tens of 2D nanosheets (petals) with thickness on the nanometer scale, ca. 50–70 nm, slightly curved, and densely interpenetrated (b). Each nanopetal was constructed from nanobricks (c). The fabrication of stable 3D flower-like hierarchical architectures, made by the integration of nanobuilding blocks, in this case 2D nanopetals, with some order and flexibility, is an elegant approach found in nature to increase systems stability. One very well-known example is the formation of the flower-shaped morphologies of crystallized calcium sulfate, known as desert roses. In the laboratory, these attractive architectures have been successfully fabricated for a wide variety of materials involving mainly inorganic compounds. For hybrid coordination polymers, several examples have been described and synthesized by solvothermal techniques, involving Zn2+, Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Ru2+ metal centers and carboxylic or pyridyl linkers. The crystallized products present a type I N2 adsorption isotherm, indicating the precipitation of a microporous system with a surface area of ca. 300 m2·g–1, which corresponded to a considerably high value for an as-synthesized product. Most of this surface area was in the range of the micropore.
